Meade Johnson and Leonard
Emmert were nominated for presidency of the Student Council for
next year by the undergraduate
classes at the assembly yesterday.
Final elections will be held today
from 12.30 to 2 o'clock and everyone eligible was urged to vote by
President McClean.
The nominations followed a
meeting devoted to the induction 01
twelve students into the local chap
ter of Pi D. E., the national honorary journalism fraternity.

merely keeping quiet will cause things
to come out all right, and that attacks on rights or liberties will "blow
over," are out-moded. It might. But
this affair of the Oath Bill does not
look like just a bit of meaningless
wind to us. And recent developments
of intolerance throughout the world
make an analogy with the situations
in this country which is uncomfortably close.
James J. McGuirck, state commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars,
stated Wednesday: "If Governor Nice
does go through with his expressed
intention of vetoing this bill, you may
be sure that we will be back with
all the influence and pressure in the
world to pass another one at the first
session of the Legislature." And this
one is to have "teeth in it." No compromise in this!
The fight may be carried on in a
gentlemanly way, but it can not be
half-hearted. The scholar and the intellectual will have to rouse themselves from their disregard of "affairs
of the world" if they are to save
themselves from the forces of reaction. If they have any regard for social or scientific progress they will
have to make their voices heardeffectively. Too long a time must not
be spent in bandying words over
this and that side issue. The question
is clearly drawn now, as it was not
before; and this main issue of freedom of thought and tolerance of
opinion must have all others subordinated to it if the fight is to be carried to a successful conclusion. The
strength of the lobbies, particularly
the American Legion, has been shown
all too well before.
The place of the Hopkins, and all
the students and teachers and others
associated with it is to lead the fight
in Maryland. Inaction is out-moded!
N. P.

By JACK STEIN
Before leaving, my dear readers,
I want to offer a public service. Below is printed some very very good
advice. It was compiled by students
of B. I. T. and is a worthwhile epic.
The list immediately following could
properly be entitled, Do's and Don'ts
With the Girl Friend.
1. Compliment the girl occasionally.
(Even flattery is good when used
with discrimination.)
2. Notice if she has anything new,
and tell her you like it.
3. Don't get a haircut just before
a date.
4. Don't talk about other girls.
5. If you must have a line-have
three or four good ones, and don't
use the same one on all girls.
6. Don't try to neck a girl on the
first date.
7. Don't sit in front of her house
and honk, but go up to the door.
8. Don't wait for the last minute
to ask her for a date.
9. When you know she's interested,
show her that she has some competition.
10. Don't be too jealous of her.
11. Always appear neat.
12. Don't be conceited.
13. Don't brag.
14. Don't be too nice to her.
15. Know how to dance.
16. Don't do things for spite.
17. Don't sit around and talk to
her family if she's rarin' to go.
Don't drag another fellow
18.
along at the last minute and expect
the girl to get him a date.
19. Don't smoke incessantly.
20. Don't tell her to shut up.
21. Don't tell dirty jokes.
22. Have something planned to do.
23. Be courteous.
24. Do little things she likes.
25. Talk about things in which she's
interested.
26. Don't tell everyone what you
did on the date.
27. Be on time for a date.
28. Don't come early and gripe because she's not ready.
29. Don't act bored-even if you
are.
30. Be natural.
,31. Don't try to be funny.
32. Don't try to be conspicuous at
a public place.
33. Don't be sarcastic.
34. Don't be pulling sashes, zippers, unbuttoning buttons, playing
with her hair, et cetera.
35. If you must neck (after the
first date), for heaven's sake, have
good technique.

University In Exile
Thriving In Gotham
New York, May 17—Exile has
proved sweet to a group of hard-driving scholars who teach here the creeds
that cost them their jobs in Germany.
As faculty members of the University in Exile the scholar—seventeen
of them, including one Italian—have
made themselves at home quickly.
Some are taking out citizenship papers and others argue seriously whether they would go back to Berlin
even on the old basis of intellectual
freedom.
The university is run as a graduate
college in connection with the new
school research on W. Twelfth street.
Established two years ago as a haven
for a few of the instructors dropped
from German faculties by the Nazis,
it has become a permanent institution.
"We got the cream of the 1,200
ousted by the Nazis," said Dr. Alvin
Johnson today. Dr. Johnson is president of the new school and sponsor
of the University in Exile.
Hardly had the scholars arrived, he
related, before they found for themselves Spuyten Duyvil, an "unspoiled"
district named like Brooklyn and Harlem by the old-time Dutch. There they
obtained comfortable quarters and
began to recreate some of the atmosphere of a German university town.
Over coffee cups—they don't go in
much for beer—they talked of trends
and topics verboten in their homeland.
Dr. Emil Lederer, noted social theorist, is writing a tome on technological unemployment for the League
of Nations. And strapping Karl
Brandt, whose idea of fun is an auto
tour to get his information first hand,
is putting out a monumental _handbook on the world's farm products.
The others all have their projects.

"All public officials have to take
such an oath. All the members of the
Army and Navy have to take it. All
members of our organizations have
to take it. Why shouldn't the teachers, Who have our children in their
charge in the schools, at public expense, take it?
"If Governor Nice does go through
with his expressed intention of vetoing this bill, you may be sure that
we will be back with all the influence
and pressure in the world to pass another one at the first session of the
Legislature."
Features White's Statement
•
The main article on the first page
of the "local news" section was a
feature of two columns quoting Delegate John S. White, introducer of
the bill passed last session, and Governor Nice. Delegate White's statement follows:
"While I have every respect for
Governor Nice, I think that he is misguided in his stand on the teachers'
oath bill.
"It is his right and prerogative to
veto any bill when he can support his
veto with good reasons.
"His reasons in this case, though,
I do not feel are sufficient. However,
if he does veto this bill, I will be right
back with another one the first time
that the Legislature meets, and it will
be passed just like this one was.
"The Governor said that the bill
has no penalty. It provides that no
person can teach in any school in the
State which draws money from the
State who does not take the oath of
allegiance. That is what we want. We
want to keep those persons out of the
teaching profession in Maryland who
inculcate seditions and subversive
doctrines.
"If the prospective teacher would
not take the oath he couldn't teach.
That accomplishes the purposes for
which we are driving.
"If the Governor does not feel that
this bill is strong enough, tben we will
come back with one that will meet
any condition that he wants. And he
will have to sign it on the face of the
statement that he has made containing the reasons for his proposed action.
"While I respect the Governor's office and his rights on legislation, I
do feel that he should carefully consider his action.
"This bill received 132 out of 148
votes in the two branches of the Assembly, and yet, by his one vote, he
can destroy the will of that great majority in the legislative branch of the
government.
"I am going to make a thorough
study of just how stringent legislation against Communistic teaching
can be made. Then we will have a bill
that will meet all conditions."
Governor Nice, after declaring that
he would sign a bill with teeth in it,
said that such a measure should contain provision for allowing foreign
scholars to teach in the State.

FOOTBALL MEN OUT!

Today at 4 P. M. all members of
last year's football team and those
interested in trying out for this
year's squad are requested to report to the gym for an organization meeting..

The First Presbyterian Church tied
the Johns Hopkins Faculty Badminton Team by a score of 3 to 3 in their
match at the gym last Tuesday.
This tie gives the Hopkins team a
less chance of winning the championship of the Baltimore Badminton
League.
However, there are two
games still to be played. The Y. M.
C. A. and the Racquet Club Badminton teams will be met on May 23 and
May 30, respectively.
Jimmy Benson, of the Hopkins Faculty, has the best record on his team.
He has not lost a single game during
the season, both in singles and in
doubles. Reuben Baer also has not
lost a singles match.
Jimmy Benson won his singles
match and then paired with Dr. von
der Muhll to score again in the doubles. Reuben Baer scored the other
point for the Hopkins in the singles.

Class Champions
Decided On Friday
Mechanics Take Frosh Title; CivilsGas, Intelligentsia Unbeaten;
Frat Race Close
Last Friday was a crucial day in
intra-mural circles.

Games played

that afternoon decided the class championships. In the Frosh League the
Mechanics nosed out the Artists, 9-6,
to take the Frosh title. A scratch
hit by Skinner, Mechanics pitcher,
with the bases loaded, was enough to
give the Mechs a sufficient lead. This
game was the most closely contested
of all played in the Freshmen League.
The Civils-Gas practically walked
away with the Soph League. These
athletes had little trouble in subdueing all opposition and finished the
regular schedule with three wins and
no losses.

Intelligentsia Show Way
Led by Dick Byer, the Intelligentsia of the Junior League showed themselves as good performers, coming
out ahead of three Engineer teams.
The Intells were pressed to win in
only one game, that with the third
place Gas Civils. A few well placed
hits at the right time, however, was
enough to put the Intelligentsia on
the long end of a 15-to-13 score. These
boys had the best record of all teams
in the league, winning four games and
suffering no losses.

Frat Races Close
In what was probably the most exciting of all frat games, the third
place Tau Alpha defeated Phi Alpha
leader of Division B, 4 to 3. This
leaves the championship of Group B
between Phi Alpha, Phi Sig and Tau
Alpha. S. P. E. has undisputed possession of first place in Division A
with four wins and no losses. Tied
for second place are Pi Lam and 0. K.
0., both having suffered one loss in
five starts The former can upset the
dope-bucket by defeating S. P. E.
today. This would necessitate a threeway playoff.

Johnson, Emmert Put Up

Meade Johnson and Leonard
Emmert were nominated for presidency of the Student Council for
next year by the undergraduate
classes at the assembly yesterday.
Final elections will be held today
from 12.30 to 2 o'clock and everyone eligible was urged to vote by
President McClean.
The nominations followed a
meeting devoted to the induction 01
twelve students into the local chap
ter of Pi D. E., the national honorary journalism fraternity.

merely keeping quiet will cause things
to come out all right, and that attacks on rights or liberties will "blow
over," are out-moded. It might. But
this affair of the Oath Bill does not
look like just a bit of meaningless
wind to us. And recent developments
of intolerance throughout the world
make an analogy with the situations
in this country which is uncomfortably close.
James J. McGuirck, state commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars,
stated Wednesday: "If Governor Nice
does go through with his expressed
intention of vetoing this bill, you may
be sure that we will be back with
all the influence and pressure in the
world to pass another one at the first
session of the Legislature." And this
one is to have "teeth in it." No compromise in this!
The fight may be carried on in a
gentlemanly way, but it can not be
half-hearted. The scholar and the intellectual will have to rouse themselves from their disregard of "affairs
of the world" if they are to save
themselves from the forces of reaction. If they have any regard for social or scientific progress they will
have to make their voices heardeffectively. Too long a time must not
be spent in bandying words over
this and that side issue. The question
is clearly drawn now, as it was not
before; and this main issue of freedom of thought and tolerance of
opinion must have all others subordinated to it if the fight is to be carried to a successful conclusion. The
strength of the lobbies, particularly
the American Legion, has been shown
all too well before.
The place of the Hopkins, and all
the students and teachers and others
associated with it is to lead the fight
in Maryland. Inaction is out-moded!

By JACK STEIN
Before leaving, my dear readers,
I want to offer a public service. Below is printed some very very good
advice. It was compiled by students
of B. I. T. and is a worthwhile epic.
The list immediately following could
properly be entitled, Do's and Don'ts
With the Girl Friend.
1. Compliment the girl occasionally.
(Even flattery is good when used
with discrimination.)
2. Notice if she has anything new,
and tell her you like it.
3. Don't get a haircut just before
a date.
4. Don't talk about other girls.
5. If you must have a line-have
three or four good ones, and don't
use the same one on all girls.
6. Don't try to neck a girl on the
first date.
7. Don't sit in front of her house
and honk, but go up to the door.
8. Don't wait for the last minute
to ask her for a date.
9. When you know she's interested,
show her that she has some competition.
10. Don't be too jealous of her.
11. Always appear neat.
12. Don't be conceited.
13. Don't brag.
14. Don't be too nice to her.
15. Know how to dance.
16. Don't do things for spite.
17. Don't sit around and talk to
her family if she's rarin' to go.
Don't drag another fellow
18.
along at the last minute and expect
the girl to get him a date.
19. Don't smoke incessantly.
20. Don't tell her to shut up.
21. Don't tell dirty jokes.
22. Have something planned to do.
23. Be courteous.
24. Do little things she likes.
25. Talk about things in which she's
interested.
26. Don't tell everyone what you
did on the date.
27. Be on time for a date.
28. Don't come early and gripe because she's not ready.
29. Don't act bored-even if you
are.
30. Be natural.
,31. Don't try to be funny.
32. Don't try to be conspicuous at
a public place.
33. Don't be sarcastic.
34. Don't be pulling sashes, zippers, unbuttoning buttons, playing
with her hair, et cetera.
35. If you must neck (after the
first date), for heaven's sake, have
good technique.

I print a few more excerpts from

children, can you tell me why?"
"I have no children yet. My husband is a bus driver, and works day
and night."
"Mrs. Brown has had no clothing
for a year, and has been visited by
the clergy."
"Sir, I am forwarding my marriage
certificate and my two children, one
of which was a mistake as you can
see."

University In Exile
Thriving In Gotham
New York, May 17—Exile has
proved sweet to a group of hard-driving scholars who teach here the creeds
that cost them their jobs in Germany.
As faculty members of the University in Exile the scholar—seventeen
of them, including one Italian—have
made themselves at home quickly.
Some are taking out citizenship papers and others argue seriously whether they would go back to Berlin
even on the old basis of intellectual
freedom.
The university is run as a graduate
college in connection with the new
school research on W. Twelfth street.
Established two years ago as a haven
for a few of the instructors dropped
from German faculties by the Nazis,
it has become a permanent institution.
"We got the cream of the 1,200
ousted by the Nazis," said Dr. Alvin
Johnson today. Dr. Johnson is president of the new school and sponsor
of the University in Exile.
Hardly had the scholars arrived, he
related, before they found for themselves Spuyten Duyvil, an "unspoiled"
district named like Brooklyn and Harlem by the old-time Dutch. There they
obtained comfortable quarters and
began to recreate some of the atmosphere of a German university town.
Over coffee cups—they don't go in
much for beer—they talked of trends
and topics verboten in their homeland.
Dr. Emil Lederer, noted social theorist, is writing a tome on technological unemployment for the League
of Nations. And strapping Karl
Brandt, whose idea of fun is an auto
tour to get his information first hand,
is putting out a monumental _handbook on the world's farm products.
The others all have their projects.

"All public officials have to take
such an oath. All the members of the
Army and Navy have to take it. All
members of our organizations have
to take it. Why shouldn't the teachers, Who have our children in their
charge in the schools, at public expense, take it?
"If Governor Nice does go through
with his expressed intention of vetoing this bill, you may be sure that
we will be back with all the influence
and pressure in the world to pass another one at the first session of the
Legislature."
Features White's Statement
•
The main article on the first page
of the "local news" section was a
feature of two columns quoting Delegate John S. White, introducer of
the bill passed last session, and Governor Nice. Delegate White's statement follows:
"While I have every respect for
Governor Nice, I think that he is misguided in his stand on the teachers'
oath bill.
"It is his right and prerogative to
veto any bill when he can support his
veto with good reasons.
"His reasons in this case, though,
I do not feel are sufficient. However,
if he does veto this bill, I will be right
back with another one the first time
that the Legislature meets, and it will
be passed just like this one was.
"The Governor said that the bill
has no penalty. It provides that no
person can teach in any school in the
State which draws money from the
State who does not take the oath of
allegiance. That is what we want. We
want to keep those persons out of the
teaching profession in Maryland who
inculcate seditions and subversive
doctrines.
"If the prospective teacher would
not take the oath he couldn't teach.
That accomplishes the purposes for
which we are driving.
"If the Governor does not feel that
this bill is strong enough, tben we will
come back with one that will meet
any condition that he wants. And he
will have to sign it on the face of the
statement that he has made containing the reasons for his proposed action.
"While I respect the Governor's office and his rights on legislation, I
do feel that he should carefully consider his action.
"This bill received 132 out of 148
votes in the two branches of the Assembly, and yet, by his one vote, he
can destroy the will of that great majority in the legislative branch of the
government.
"I am going to make a thorough
study of just how stringent legislation against Communistic teaching
can be made. Then we will have a bill
that will meet all conditions."
Governor Nice, after declaring that
he would sign a bill with teeth in it,
said that such a measure should contain provision for allowing foreign
scholars to teach in the State.

FOOTBALL MEN OUT!

Today at 4 P. M. all members of
last year's football team and those
interested in trying out for this
year's squad are requested to report to the gym for an organization meeting..

The First Presbyterian Church tied
the Johns Hopkins Faculty Badminton Team by a score of 3 to 3 in their
match at the gym last Tuesday.
This tie gives the Hopkins team a
less chance of winning the championship of the Baltimore Badminton
League.
However, there are two
games still to be played. The Y. M.
C. A. and the Racquet Club Badminton teams will be met on May 23 and
May 30, respectively.
Jimmy Benson, of the Hopkins Faculty, has the best record on his team.
He has not lost a single game during
the season, both in singles and in
doubles. Reuben Baer also has not
lost a singles match.
Jimmy Benson won his singles
match and then paired with Dr. von
der Muhll to score again in the doubles. Reuben Baer scored the other
point for the Hopkins in the singles.

Class Champions
Decided On Friday
Mechanics Take Frosh Title; CivilsGas, Intelligentsia Unbeaten;
Frat Race Close
Last Friday was a crucial day in
intra-mural circles.

Games played

that afternoon decided the class championships. In the Frosh League the
Mechanics nosed out the Artists, 9-6,
to take the Frosh title. A scratch
hit by Skinner, Mechanics pitcher,
with the bases loaded, was enough to
give the Mechs a sufficient lead. This
game was the most closely contested
of all played in the Freshmen League.
The Civils-Gas practically walked
away with the Soph League. These
athletes had little trouble in subdueing all opposition and finished the
regular schedule with three wins and
no losses.

Frat Races Close
In what was probably the most exciting of all frat games, the third
place Tau Alpha defeated Phi Alpha
leader of Division B, 4 to 3. This
leaves the championship of Group B
between Phi Alpha, Phi Sig and Tau
Alpha. S. P. E. has undisputed possession of first place in Division A
with four wins and no losses. Tied
for second place are Pi Lam and 0. K.
0., both having suffered one loss in
five starts The former can upset the
dope-bucket by defeating S. P. E.
today. This would necessitate a threeway playoff.
